ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic tree biology, architecture, stand dynamics. Also learn some basic lab skills, including tree height.
This class is a wonderful dive into the biology of trees!

I learned SO MUCH from this class. I mean really. I learned about tree anatomy (in a way that was super logical and easy to understand!), the function and properties of wood, trees' role in long term environmental history, and the role of all of these things in certain areas of the humanities.
Biological foundations of trees, systems within trees and their relationships, cultural significance of trees and history of forest systems.
So much trees knowledge!

I learned a lot about how trees function and their role in the larger environment. The class taught me about the biology of trees and how all of their systems work together in order to survive and respond to environmental factors. I also learned about how trees are used by humans and the different landscape changes that have occurred in New England over the past 15,000 years.
I learned the mechanical functions of a tree and a little bit of Northeastern history.
I learned more than I even imagined I could about tree physiology, plant biology, and wood properties/uses.
Tree biology and cultural info surrounding trees and their use

Developed an awareness of trees both on a biological and global level. I enjoyed the parts of the course related to human usage e.g. furniture as well as the role of trees in climate change mitigation.
I learned an immense amount about trees, a lot more than I was expecting. It is a great class to work on problem solving skills as well.

Learned how trees works and then we learned about their value to society and the earth. I personally learned to appreciate trees and even ended up looking at the differently by the end of the semester.
Learned tree anatomy and the ways in which trees are used in our everyday life. I am also now aware of different pests and pathogens affecting trees as well as basic forest dynamics.
I now feel that I have gained a solid foundation on the inner workings of trees as well as their cultural and global importance.
I learned about trees environmental and global significance. For example, I learned about anatomy as well as social implications for tree-related things like invasive species.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - well organized, fair grading, teaching team always well coordinated, amazing professor, good feedback on all submissions
Weaknesses - sections often felt like they didn't add much substance to course
This class is great as is. Professor Brodersen is super engaging and clearly knows so many fun facts about trees.

No weaknesses at all. Work back in a prompt manner. Tons of opportunities for review. Lectures genuinely engaging and course content very cross-disciplinary.  The prof and teaching team are excellent. Lots of in class demonstrations and class outings. Exams were manageable and allowed for students to demonstrate knowledge that they had rather than trying to "catch you". The only bummer about this class is how few people get to take it compared to how many people want to take it.

Strengths: clear expectations, realistic learning objectives, interesting material, very structured, interesting field trips

Weaknesses: discussion section sometimes didn't have enough time for the activities we were expected to complete.

Such exciting material!!

Lectures were sometimes a little dry, but overall the enthusiasm Craig had really shined through and made this class a worthwhile experience.

The organization and instructions around exams could be improved. It was unclear how to study and what expectations were for how exams would be graded.
Broderson is an amazing instructor! This course was engaging and the sections were always new and unexpected!
This is the best class Ive taken at Yale. Extremely engaging lectures and fun, doable assignments. The only change Id ask for is a later Thursday discussion section (9:25 was too early for me).
Strengths are the information and Professor, fun section activities too, weakness is slides could be a little more organized
Lectures can sometimes be a bit disengaging and unorganized. It would be helpful to have stronger course organization and clearer info on what will be tested and expected to know

Strengths: I liked how interactive discussion sections were and how we went on different field trips.
Weaknesses: an hour and 15 minute lecture on top of discussion section is a lot. Maybe 50 minute lectures would allow me to keep focus.
I wish lectures were shorter but other than that most of the course was strong.

Strengths: Professor Brodersen is a very passionate lecturer. Some topics are very interesting. The homework is very light with only 6 assignments throughout the semester. 
Weaknesses: Some lectures could get long and tedious.
The strengths of this course are the engagement of the lectures and the style of the tests. The tests both require knowledge of class material but also requires creativity in answering the questions.

I really loved all aspects of this course. The lectures were interesting and engaging. I really enjoyed the assignments and section activities, especially because the assignments were more hands on and came at plant science from a different more practical angle.

Stength: grading/overall transparency 

Weakness: lecture formats were sometimes a little confusing. For example the hormone lecture was a little hard to follow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would recommend to any EVST student, especially in combination with Forest Dynamics
Yes!

Absolutely. For starters, the content in the class is very interesting, and it completely changed my perception of the world around me. Second, Professor Broderson is an amazing lecturer who is clearly invested in what he teaches. He is also very supportive and understanding of students and wants nothing more than for them to succeed and learn.

THIS IS A MUST TAKE CLASS AT YALE. I came in to this class with ZERO science knowledge. I mean really zero. I am humanities major and the only Yale QR/SC classes I took up to this point was econ 115. I also haven't taken bio since freshman year of high school, and not only was I able to handle all of the material, but I loved learning it. The knowledge I learned in this class will genuinely enhance my studies in the humanities.  I was actually almost sad the day that class ended knowing that I wouldn't be able to come back. The teaching team was also stellar- they were very approachable and used section time very well. The class took lots of interesting field trips and outings that coincided with class content. I cannot say enough great things about this class- really its only problem was the sad reality that so many of my peers won't get the opportunity to take this class. Calling it a gut would be a disservice, you will genuinely enjoy this class, and as long as you go to lecture and engage with the course material, you will do well.

YES. This is one of the only Yale courses I have taken in which I have felt like the learning expectations were clear. The material is interesting and the instructor takes great care to apply the material to current world issues. Exams are comprehensible and I felt very prepared for all exams and assignments we were expected to complete. This is the only time where I have genuinely enjoyed STEM and has lead me to become more involved in other courses. TAKE THIS CLASS
Yes!!! Awesome course for non-EVST majors and non-STEM people looking for a science credit. I have a deep love of trees, so the course was perfect for me.

Yes! I found it to be super informative and interesting. I wondered how there would be enough information on trees to fill a semester, but I found the information was always new and built on the previous material. Professor Brodersen is a great lecturer and he made class informative and fun with his demonstrations and slides.
BEST CLASS EVER. I love trees and I wish I would have taken this class freshman year so I would have had time to change my major.

I would say although it is an interesting course, prepare for a high workload and exams with lots of details necessary. It went much further into the science (down to the inter-cellular level) than I thought!
Yes, so fun to learn about trees
Yes if they have some background in plant biology - I think the material would be too complex for a complete beginner.
Yes, it is really interesting and the grading is fair.

Yes, especially if you're interested in an environmental science major and are curious of what the EVST classes are like. Not all classes are as fun as engaging as this one, but it will get you excited for the major nonetheless.

I would definitely recommend this class to others. Going into the class, I was unsure of my major, and was largely looking at other things. This course ignited in me an interest in plant science, and I am now planning on majoring in environmental science, possibly in this realm of study. Even beyond that, I feel that it is a class that is important and interesting for both science and non science majors alike.
Yes! All the assignments and field trip opportunities were so fun and exciting. As a first-year, I feel like this course helped me learn more about Yale as a whole, which is very exciting.
